description: Banded Demoiselle - A striking damselfly with metallic blue-green body and dark-tinted wings, found near rivers and streams.
Beautiful Demoiselle - Similar to the Banded Demoiselle but with broader wings; males have a metallic blue body, females are green-bronze.
Broad-bodied Chaser - A medium-sized dragonfly with a broad, flattened abdomen; males are powder blue, and females are yellow-brown.
Buff-tailed Bumblebee - One of the most common bumblebees in the UK, characterized by a buff-colored 'tail' and two yellow bands.
Cave Spider - A large, dark-colored spider typically found in caves, cellars, and tunnels. Despite their intimidating appearance, they are harmless to humans.
Comma Butterfly - Recognizable by its ragged wing edges and orange-brown wings with dark spots. The underside of the wing has a white 'C' shape.
Common Blue Butterfly - The most widespread blue butterfly in the UK; males have bright blue wings, while females are brown with orange spots.
Common Crab Spider - Known for its crab-like appearance and ability to walk sideways. They can change color to match their surroundings.
Common Darter Dragonfly - A small, agile dragonfly; males are red, and females are yellow-brown. They are frequently seen in late summer near water bodies.
Common Fox Spider - A ground-dwelling spider with excellent vision, known for its speed and hunting prowess. Found in heathlands and grasslands.
Common Frog - Widespread amphibian with smooth skin, varying in color from green to brown, and dark patches. Prefers damp habitats.
Common Lizard - The UK's most common reptile, exhibiting a variety of colors from brown to green. Often seen basking in sunny spots.
Common Toad - Characterized by warty skin and short legs. They have a distinctive hopping gait and are commonly found in gardens and woodlands.
Death Cap Mushroom - A highly toxic mushroom with a pale green or yellow cap and white gills. Responsible for the majority of fatal mushroom poisonings.
Devil’s Coach Horse - A large, black beetle known for raising its abdomen when threatened, resembling a scorpion. Common in gardens and under logs.
European Adder - The UK's only venomous snake, identifiable by the dark zigzag pattern along its back. Generally shy and avoids human contact.
European Garden Spider - Also known as the cross orb-weaver, it has a distinctive white cross pattern on its abdomen. Builds spiral wheel-shaped webs.
False Black Widow Spider - Often mistaken for the black widow, it has a dark, bulbous abdomen with cream markings. Its venom is not considered dangerous.
Fen Raft Spider - One of the UK's largest spiders, capable of walking on water. Found in wetlands and fens, it preys on insects and even small fish.
Fly Agaric Mushroom - Iconic red mushroom with white spots, commonly depicted in fairy tales. While toxic, it is rarely fatal and is found in woodlands.
Grass Snake - Non-venomous snake with a distinctive yellow collar behind the head. Prefers wet habitats and is an excellent swimmer.
Great Crested Newt - The largest of the UK's newts, with warty skin and a prominent crest along the back of males during the breeding season. Found in ponds and wetlands.
Hammock-web Spider - Constructs horizontal, sheet-like webs resembling a hammock. Common in gardens and woodlands, they are harmless to humans.
Harlequin Ladybird - An invasive species with variable coloration, ranging from orange to black with varying numbers of spots. Known to outcompete native ladybirds.
Holly Blue Butterfly - Small butterfly with pale blue wings
Establishment Means: the undersides are silvery with small black spots. Often seen around holly and ivy plants.

description: Jelly Ear Fungus - Ear-shaped, gelatinous fungus that grows on elder trees. Brown to dark purple in color and commonly used in Asian cuisine.
Lace Web Spider - Recognizable by the lace-like pattern on its brown body. Builds messy, lace-like webs on walls and fences.
Large Red Damselfly - One of the first damselflies to emerge in spring
Establishment Means: characterized by its bright red abdomen and black legs. Found near ponds and slow-moving water.

description: Marmalade Hoverfly - A small hoverfly with distinctive orange and black bands. Mimics the appearance of a wasp but is harmless and an important pollinator.
Marsh Frog - The largest frog species in the UK, with a loud, distinctive call. Prefers marshes and wetlands in southeastern England.
Migrant Hawker Dragonfly - A medium-sized dragonfly with a dark abdomen marked with blue spots. Often seen in late summer and autumn, feeding on flying insects.
Natterjack Toad - Notable for the yellow line running down its back and its loud, rasping call. Inhabits sandy heaths and coastal dunes.
Painted Lady Butterfly - A migratory butterfly with orange, black, and white patterned wings. Travels from North Africa to the UK during summer.
Palmate Newt - A small newt with smooth skin
Establishment Means: males develop webbed hind feet and a filament at the end of the tail during breeding season. Found in ponds and wetlands.

description: Panther Cap Mushroom - A toxic mushroom with a brown cap covered in white spots. Resembles the Fly Agaric but is more dangerous if ingested.
Peacock Butterfly - Easily identifiable by the eye-like markings on its wings, which deter predators. Common in gardens and meadows.
Raft Spider - A large spider that can run across the water's surface, commonly found in wetland areas.
Red Admiral Butterfly - A striking butterfly with black wings adorned with red bands and white spots. Often seen in gardens feeding on nectar.
Red-tailed Bumblebee - A bumblebee species with a distinctive red "tail" and black body. Common in gardens and grasslands.
Running Crab Spider - A fast-moving spider that does not spin webs but actively hunts prey.
Sand Lizard - A reptile with green coloration and black markings, found in sandy heathlands.
Scarlet Elf Cup Fungus - A bright red fungus shaped like a cup, typically found in damp woodlands.
Seven-spot Ladybird - A common ladybird with red wing covers and seven black spots.
Shaggy Inkcap Mushroom - A tall, white mushroom that turns black and dissolves as it matures.
Slow Worm - A legless lizard that resembles a snake but can blink and shed its tail.
Small Tortoiseshell Butterfly - A butterfly with orange and black wings, known for its resilience in winter.
Smooth Snake - A non-venomous snake with a smooth, brownish body, often found in grasslands.
Southern Hawker Dragonfly - A large dragonfly with green and blue markings, common around ponds.
Speckled Wood Butterfly - A butterfly with brown wings covered in cream speckles, found in woodlands.
Stag Beetle - A large beetle with mandibles resembling antlers, often found in woodlands.
Stinkhorn Fungus - A foul-smelling fungus that emerges from an egg-like structure.
Stripe-legged Spider - A spider species known for its striped legs and fast movements.
Thick-legged Flower Beetle - A metallic green beetle with thick legs, commonly found on flowers.
Tree Bumblebee - A bumblebee species that nests in trees and has a ginger-colored thorax.
Wall Lizard - A small lizard with a flattened body, found in rocky habitats.
Alpine Newt - A small amphibian with a dark back and orange belly, often found in mountain streams and ponds.
Edible Frog - A greenish frog native to Europe, known for its loud croaking and semi-aquatic lifestyle.
Emperor Dragonfly - One of the UK's largest dragonflies, with a bright blue abdomen and powerful flight.
Orange Peel Fungus - A cup-shaped fungus with a bright orange color, typically found on soil and rotting wood.
Balearic Shearwater - A medium-sized seabird that migrates across the Atlantic, often seen off the UK coast in winter.
Barn Owl - A nocturnal bird of prey with a heart-shaped face and silent flight, commonly found in open countryside.
Bearded Tit - A small, striking bird with a long tail and distinctive black "moustache" markings on males.
Black Guillemot - A black and white seabird that nests on rocky coasts, known for its red legs and white wing patches.
Black Redstart - A small passerine bird with dark plumage and a distinctive orange-red tail.
Blackcap - A warbler with a melodious song, males have a black cap while females have a brown cap.
Black-headed Gull - A medium-sized gull with a black head in summer, white head in winter, and red legs.
Black-throated Thrush - A rare winter visitor to the UK, a thrush with dark plumage and a pale throat.
Blue Tit - A small, acrobatic bird with a bright blue cap, yellow underparts, and a black eye stripe.
Brambling - A small finch with a striking orange breast, white belly, and black and brown markings.
Carrion Crow - A large, all-black crow commonly seen scavenging in urban and rural areas.
Chaffinch - A colorful finch with a blue-grey head, pink breast, and white wing bars.
Coal Tit - A small tit with a black cap, white cheeks, and a preference for coniferous woodland.
Collared Dove - A pale grey dove with a distinctive black collar on the back of its neck.
Common Blackbird - A familiar garden bird, males are black with a yellow beak, while females are brown.
Common Crossbill - A finch with a distinctive crossed bill, adapted for extracting seeds from pine cones.
Common Kingfisher - A small bird with brilliant blue and orange plumage, often seen near rivers and lakes.
Common Linnet - A small finch with brown streaked plumage and a reddish breast in males.
Common Moorhen - A medium-sized waterbird with dark plumage, red and yellow bill, and long legs.
Common Redshank - A wader with long red legs and a straight bill, found in wetlands and estuaries.
Common Sandpiper - A small, brownish wader with a distinctive bobbing motion along the water’s edge.
Common Snipe - A cryptically colored wader with a long, straight bill, found in marshes and wet grasslands.
Common Swift - A fast-flying bird that spends most of its life in the air, recognizable by its sickle-shaped wings.
Common Wood Pigeon - The UK's largest pigeon, with grey plumage, white neck patches, and a distinctive cooing call.
Cormorant - A large black waterbird with a long neck, often seen drying its wings after diving for fish.
Corn Bunting - A large, streaky brown bunting with a thick bill, often seen perched on wires in farmland.
Corncrake - A secretive, ground-dwelling bird with a rasping call, typically found in tall grass meadows.
Cuckoo - A migratory bird known for its distinctive "cuckoo" call and habit of laying eggs in other birds' nests.
Dusky Warbler - A small, brownish warbler with a faint eye stripe, occasionally seen in the UK during migration.
Eurasian Blackbird - A common garden thrush, males are black with a yellow beak, females are brown.
Eurasian Curlew - A large wader with a long, downward-curved bill, found in coastal and wetland areas.
Eurasian Magpie - A striking black and white bird with iridescent blue-green feathers and a long tail.
Eurasian Wren - A tiny, brown bird with a loud song and an upright tail, commonly found in hedgerows and gardens.
European Goldfinch - A brightly colored finch with a red face, black and white head, and yellow wing patches.
European Greenfinch - A chunky finch with greenish plumage and yellow flashes on the wings and tail.
European Nightjar - A nocturnal bird with cryptic plumage, known for its churring song and silent flight.
European Robin - A small bird with a bright red breast, commonly associated with winter and gardens.
European Starling - A medium-sized bird with glossy black plumage speckled with white, known for its mimicry skills.
European Stonechat - A small, perching bird with an orange breast and black head, commonly seen in heathlands.
Firecrest - A tiny songbird with a distinctive fiery orange crest, greenish upperparts, and white underparts.
Goldfinch - A small finch with a bright red face, black and white head, and yellow wing patches.
Great Crested Grebe - A water bird with ornate head plumes, white face, and chestnut frill during the breeding season.
Great Spotted Woodpecker - A medium-sized woodpecker with black and white plumage and a distinctive red patch on the lower belly.
Great Tit - A large tit with a black head and neck, white cheeks, and olive upperparts.
Grey Heron - A tall, long-legged wading bird with grey plumage and a long, pointed yellow bill.
Hen Harrier - A bird of prey with males displaying grey plumage and black wingtips, while females are brown with a white rump.
Herring Gull - A large gull with grey back, white underparts, and pink legs.
House Sparrow - A small bird with brown and grey plumage, males have black bibs.
Jackdaw - A small, black crow with a distinctive grey nape and pale eyes.
Kestrel - A small falcon with pointed wings and a long tail, often seen hovering.
Little Egret - A small white heron with black legs and yellow feet.
Little Owl - A small owl with a flat-topped head, yellow eyes, and spotted brown plumage.
Little Tern - A small seabird with a white forehead, black cap, and yellow bill.
Long-tailed Tit - A small bird with a distinctive long tail and fluffy, pinkish-white body.
Mallard Duck - A common duck with males displaying iridescent green heads and females mottled brown.
Marsh Harrier - A large bird of prey with long wings and tail, males are grey and brown, females are mostly brown.
Meadow Pipit - A small, streaky brown bird with pale underparts, commonly found in open habitats.
Mute Swan - A large white waterbird with an orange bill and black knob at the base.
Northern Lapwing - A wader with a distinctive crest, black and white plumage, and iridescent green back.
Northern Wheatear - A small passerine bird with grey upperparts, white underparts, and a distinctive white rump.
Pallas's Warbler - A tiny warbler with greenish upperparts, yellowish underparts, and a distinctive yellow stripe over the eye.
Peregrine Falcon - A large falcon with blue-grey back, barred white underparts, and a black head.
Pied Wagtail - A small bird with black upperparts, white face and underparts, and a long tail.
Pomarine Skua - A large seabird with dark plumage, white wing patches, and spoon-shaped central tail feathers.
Red Kite - A medium-large bird of prey with reddish-brown body, forked tail, and distinctive white patches under the wings.
Red-backed Shrike - A small bird with a grey head, reddish-brown back, and black mask through the eye.
Red-flanked Bluetail - A small passerine bird with blue upperparts, orange flanks, and white underparts.
Red-throated Diver - A medium-sized waterbird with grey head, red throat patch, and speckled grey-brown back.
Redwing - A small thrush with brown upperparts, white underparts streaked with brown, and a distinctive red flank.
Reed Bunting - A small bird with brown streaked plumage
Establishment Means: males have a black head and white collar.

description: Ring Ouzel - A medium-sized thrush with black plumage and a distinctive white crescent on the breast.
Rook - A large black bird with a bare, greyish-white face and a peaked crown.
Roseate Tern - A medium-sized tern with pale grey upperparts, white underparts with a slight pinkish hue, and a black cap.
Rustic Bunting - A small bunting with chestnut ear coverts, white underparts, and streaked brown upperparts.
Sand Martin - A small swallow with brown upperparts, white underparts, and a distinctive brown band across the chest.
Serin - A small finch with streaky yellow-green plumage and a distinctive yellow rump.
Shag - A medium-sized seabird with dark greenish-black plumage and a distinctive crest on the head during breeding season.
Shore Lark - A small bird with sandy-colored upperparts, yellow face with black markings, and black "horns" on the head.
Skylark - A small brown bird with streaked plumage and a distinctive crest, known for its singing flight.
Snow Bunting - A small, hardy passerine bird with white plumage in winter and brown in summer.
Song Thrush - A medium-sized thrush with brown upperparts, spotted underparts, and a distinctive song.
Spotted Flycatcher - A small, brownish-grey bird with streaked head and chest, known for catching insects in mid-air.
Tawny Owl - A stocky owl with a rounded face, dark eyes, and mottled brown plumage.
Tree Pipit - A small, streaked brown bird with a slender bill and a habit of singing in flight.
Water Rail - A secretive wading bird with brown and black plumage, long red bill, and grey underparts.
Whinchat - A small bird with a white eyebrow stripe, orange-buff breast, and dark streaked upperparts.
White-tailed Eagle - A massive bird of prey with broad wings, pale head, and a distinctive white tail.
Wood Warbler - A small warbler with bright green upperparts, yellow underparts, and a distinctive trilling song.
Woodcock - A plump, cryptically colored wading bird with a long bill and distinctive camouflaged plumage.
Woodlark - A small lark with a short tail, streaked brown plumage, and a melodious song.
Yellow Wagtail - A brightly colored wagtail with yellow underparts, olive-green back, and a long tail.
Greater Plantain - A hardy, low-growing plant with broad, ribbed leaves and tall flower spikes.
Silverweed - A creeping plant with silver-colored leaves and bright yellow flowers.
Great Willowherb - A tall, pink-flowered plant found in damp areas like riverbanks and ditches.
Spearmint - A fragrant herb with bright green, spear-shaped leaves used for culinary and medicinal purposes.
Wild Radish - A flowering plant with pale yellow or purple flowers and edible roots.
Common Chickweed - A low-growing plant with tiny white star-shaped flowers, often found in gardens and fields.
Hedge Bindweed - A climbing plant with large, trumpet-shaped white flowers that twine around hedges and fences.
Germander Speedwell - A small plant with bright blue flowers and white centers, often found in grasslands.
Red Dead-nettle - A low-growing plant with purplish-red flowers, often mistaken for stinging nettles but harmless.
Green Alkanet - A hairy plant with bright blue flowers, commonly found in shaded areas and woodland edges.
Common Milkwort - A small wildflower with pink, blue, or white flowers, often found in grasslands.
Selfheal - A low-growing plant with purple flowers, historically used in herbal medicine for wound healing.
Greater Stitchwort - A delicate white-flowered plant with deeply divided petals, found in hedgerows and woodlands.
Common Water-crowfoot - An aquatic plant with white flowers, commonly found in slow-moving water.
Marsh Horsetail - A primitive, reed-like plant that thrives in wetland areas.
Broom - A shrub with bright yellow, pea-like flowers, commonly found in heathlands.
Common Fleabane - A yellow-flowered plant found in damp meadows, historically believed to repel fleas.
Thrift (Sea Pink) - A hardy coastal plant with pink flowers, often found growing in clumps on cliffs and dunes.
Marsh-marigold - A wetland plant with large, glossy yellow flowers resembling buttercups.
Common Centaury - A small pink-flowered plant commonly found in dry grasslands and used in traditional medicine.
Cat’s-ear - A dandelion-like plant with yellow flowers and hairy leaves.
Common Toadflax - A tall plant with yellow, snapdragon-like flowers, often found along roadsides.
Meadow Crane’s-bill - A wild geranium with bright blue flowers, common in meadows.
Yellow Archangel - A woodland plant with yellow, hooded flowers and variegated leaves.
Common Valerian - A tall plant with clusters of pink or white flowers, used in herbal remedies for relaxation.
White Dead-nettle - A nettle-like plant with white flowers but lacking the sting of true nettles.
Yellow Flag Iris - A tall, bright yellow iris that thrives in wetlands and along water edges.
Common Spotted Orchid - A beautiful wild orchid with pinkish-purple flowers and dark-spotted leaves.
Sea Holly - A spiky, blue-flowered coastal plant with silvery leaves, found on sand dunes.
Great Burnet - A tall plant with deep red, round flower heads, often found in damp meadows.
Common Honeysuckle - A climbing plant with fragrant, tubular flowers that attract moths.
Marsh Violet - A small, purple-flowered plant found in damp grasslands and woodlands.
Wild Parsnip - A tall plant with yellow flowers and a strong smell, related to the cultivated parsnip.
Purple Loosestrife - A wetland plant with tall spikes of vibrant purple flowers.
Common Mouse-ear - A small white-flowered plant that grows in lawns and disturbed ground.
Common Bistort - A pink-flowered plant common in damp meadows and traditional herbal medicine.
Sneezewort - A white-flowered plant historically used as a sneezing powder.
Wood Avens - A woodland plant with yellow flowers and burr-like seed heads.
Wild Clary - A blue-flowered plant used in herbal medicine, related to sage.
Marsh Woundwort - A tall, pink-flowered plant found in wetlands, historically used for wound healing.
Meadowsweet - A fragrant, cream-colored flower found in damp meadows, used in traditional remedies.
Wild Angelica - A tall, umbel-flowered plant related to garden angelica, often found in wetlands.
Yellow Rattle - A semi-parasitic plant with yellow flowers, important in reducing grass dominance in meadows.
Wild Thyme - A low-growing, aromatic herb with small purple flowers, common in dry grasslands.
Common Hemp-nettle - A rough-stemmed plant with pink-purple flowers, often found in arable fields.
Eyebright - A small, white or purple-flowered plant historically used to treat eye infections.
Wild Garlic (Crow Garlic) - A wild relative of garlic with edible leaves and a strong smell.
Meadow Vetchling - A scrambling plant with yellow pea-like flowers, common in grasslands.
Harebell - A delicate blue-flowered plant found in dry, grassy areas.
Common Knapweed - A thistle-like plant with purple flowers, important for pollinators.
Betony - A low-growing plant with pinkish-purple flowers, used in traditional herbal medicine.
Wild Basil - A fragrant plant with pink flowers, related to culinary basil.
Dogwood - A shrub with red stems and small white flowers, commonly found in hedgerows.
Wild Marjoram - A wild herb with purple flowers, related to oregano and used in cooking.
Greater Knapweed - A tall, thistle-like plant with large purple flowers.
Wild Carrot - A wild ancestor of the cultivated carrot, with white, umbrella-shaped flower heads.
Wild Strawberry - A small, sweet wild fruit-bearing plant with white flowers.
Primrose - A woodland plant with pale yellow flowers, one of the first to bloom in spring.
Water Mint - A strongly scented mint plant with purple flowers, commonly found in wetlands.
Marsh Cinquefoil - A wetland plant with deep red flowers and creeping stems.
Herb Robert - A small, pink-flowered geranium with a distinctive smell.
Common Mallow - A tall plant with purple, funnel-shaped flowers.
Wood Sorrel - A small woodland plant with clover-like leaves and white flowers.
Lady’s Bedstraw - A yellow-flowered plant with a sweet scent, historically used in bedding.
Bugle - A creeping plant with blue flowers, often found in damp woodlands.
Wild Pansy (Heartsease) - A small violet, yellow, and white flower, historically used in herbal medicine.
Wood Anemone - A delicate white-flowered woodland plant, an early sign of spring.
Cornflower - A bright blue flower once common in cornfields, now often grown in wildflower meadows.
Red Campion - A pink-flowered plant commonly found in hedgerows and woodlands.
Hogweed - A large, white-flowered plant related to cow parsley, commonly found along roadsides.
Common Ragwort - A yellow-flowered plant toxic to livestock, but important for insects.
Common Dog Violet - A small violet-flowered plant found in grasslands and woodlands.
Cuckooflower - A pale lilac wildflower, often found in damp meadows.
Corn Marigold - A bright yellow daisy-like flower commonly found in arable fields.
Bird’s-foot Trefoil - A yellow-flowered plant commonly called "eggs and bacon" due to its color.
Blackthorn - A thorny shrub with white flowers, producing sloes used in gin-making.
Field Scabious - A purple wildflower commonly found in grasslands, important for pollinators.
Lesser Celandine - A small yellow-flowered plant that blooms in early spring.
Yarrow - A hardy, white or pink-flowered plant with feathery leaves, traditionally used in herbal medicine.
Wild Garlic (Ramsons) - A woodland plant with broad leaves and white star-like flowers, known for its strong garlic scent.
Silver Birch - A slender tree with distinctive white bark that peels in strips.
Common Hawthorn - A thorny shrub with white or pink flowers and red berries, commonly used in hedgerows.
Meadow Buttercup - A bright yellow wildflower found in meadows and pastures.
Elder - A deciduous shrub with fragrant white flowers and dark purple berries, used in food and drinks.
Common Poppy - A vibrant red wildflower with delicate petals, often associated with remembrance.
Foxglove - A tall plant with tubular, bell-shaped purple flowers, known for its medicinal properties.
Daisy - A common lawn flower with white petals and a yellow center.
Bluebell - A woodland flower with drooping, bell-shaped blue flowers that carpet the forest floor in spring.
Stinging Nettle - A green, hairy plant with stinging hairs that cause skin irritation.
English Oak - A large, long-lived tree with lobed leaves and acorns, a keystone species in British woodlands.
Dandelion - A bright yellow flower with fluffy seed heads that disperse in the wind.
Red Squirrel - A small, reddish-brown tree squirrel with a bushy tail and tufted ears.
European Rabbit - A burrowing mammal with long ears, often found in grasslands and woodlands.
Red Fox - A highly adaptable carnivore with reddish fur, a bushy tail, and a white underbelly.
European Hare - A fast-running mammal with long ears and powerful hind legs, found in open fields.
European Badger - A nocturnal mammal with black and white striped face, living in burrows called setts.
Roe Deer - A small, graceful deer with short antlers and a distinctive white rump patch.
European Mole - A small, burrowing mammal with velvety fur and powerful digging claws.
European Otter - A semi-aquatic mammal with a sleek body, webbed feet, and a thick tail.
European Water Vole - A rodent with a round face, small ears, and a plump body, often found in waterways.
Bat - A flying mammal that uses echolocation to navigate and catch insects.
Hazel Dormouse - A small, golden-brown rodent with a bushy tail, found in woodlands.
Wood Mouse - A small rodent with large eyes and ears, known for its agility and nocturnal habits.
Eurasian Beaver - A large, aquatic rodent with webbed feet and a flat, scaly tail, known for building dams.
Brown Rat - A common, adaptable rodent found in urban and rural environments.
Lesser Horseshoe Bat - A small bat with a distinctive horseshoe-shaped nose, found in caves and old buildings.
Brown Long-eared Bat - A bat species with large ears, known for its slow, fluttering flight.
Reeves's Muntjac - A small, invasive deer species with short antlers and a hunched posture.
Red Deer - The largest UK deer species, with large branching antlers in males.
Noctule Bat - One of the UK's largest bats, with a golden-brown coat and fast, high-altitude flight.
Pygmy Shrew - One of the smallest UK mammals, with a long nose and high metabolism.
Grey Seal - A large seal species with a dog-like face, found around the UK coast.
Stoat - A small carnivorous mammal with a long body and a black-tipped tail.
Natterer's Bat - A medium-sized bat with pale fur and broad wings, often roosting in old buildings.
Harbour Porpoise - A small, shy marine mammal with a rounded head and short dorsal fin.
Pipistrelle Bat Genus - A group of small bats known for their fast, fluttering flight and insectivorous diet.
Field Vole - A small rodent with short ears and a dense brown coat, found in grasslands.
Bank Vole - A small, reddish-brown rodent with a short tail, common in woodlands.
Common Shrew - A tiny insectivorous mammal with a pointed snout and velvety brown fur.
Harbour Seal - A smaller, round-headed seal found around the UK coastline.
Mouse-eared Bats - A group of bats characterized by their large, mouse-like ears.
American Mink - A non-native carnivorous mammal with dark fur, often found near water.
Fallow Deer - A medium-sized deer with a spotted coat and large, palmate antlers in males.
Weasel - A small, slender carnivore known for hunting rodents.
Greater Horseshoe Bat - A large bat species with a distinctive nose shape and strong echolocation skills.
Mammals - A diverse group of warm-blooded animals characterized by fur and milk production.
Bottlenose Dolphin - A highly intelligent marine mammal with a curved dorsal fin and a playful nature.
Mountain Hare - A species of hare that turns white in winter for camouflage in snowy landscapes.
Pine Marten - A tree-dwelling carnivore with a bushy tail and creamy throat patch.
European Polecat - A wild relative of the ferret with dark fur and a pale face mask.
Serotine Bat - A large bat that hunts beetles and other large insects at dusk.
Leisler’s Bat - A medium-sized bat with fast flight, often roosting in trees.
Yellow-necked Mouse - A larger relative of the wood mouse, with a yellowish band across its chest.
Voles - Small, stocky rodents with short tails, found in grasslands and wetlands.
Harvest Mouse - A tiny mouse with a prehensile tail, known for building nests in tall grasses.
Long-eared Bats - A group of bats with exceptionally large ears, used for sensitive hearing.
Eurasian Water Shrew - A semi-aquatic shrew with water-repellent fur and venomous saliva.
Chinese Water Deer - A small deer with large tusks instead of antlers.
House Mouse - A common rodent with grey-brown fur, often found in human dwellings.
Whiskered Brandt’s Bat - A small bat with a distinctive fur pattern and a preference for woodland habitats.
Whiskered Bat - A bat species with soft fur and a fluttery flight, often found in old buildings.
Minke Whale - A small baleen whale that frequents UK waters, recognized by its sleek body and dorsal fin.
Common Dolphin - A fast-swimming dolphin with a distinctive hourglass pattern on its sides.
Barbastelle Bat - A rare bat with dark fur and a distinctive upturned nose.
Shrews - Small, insect-eating mammals with pointed snouts and fast metabolisms.
Sika Deer - A small deer species with a spotted coat and a distinctive call.
Deer Family - A group of hoofed mammals characterized by antlers in males.
Coypu - A large, semi-aquatic rodent with orange teeth, originally introduced from South America.
Nathusius’ Pipistrelle - A migratory bat species found in the UK.
Domestic Goat - A widely kept farm animal known for its climbing ability and curiosity.
Vesper Bats - A family of bats known for their evening activity and varied diets.
Oceanic Dolphins - A diverse group of highly intelligent, social marine mammals.
Risso’s Dolphin - A large dolphin with a blunt head and distinctive scars on its body.
Wild Boar - A large, tusked mammal that roots in the ground for food.
Domestic Cat - A widely domesticated carnivore, valued for companionship and hunting.
Noctule-Serotine Bat Group - A classification of large, fast-flying bats.
Mice and Rats - A group of small, adaptable rodents found worldwide.
Brandt’s Bat - A small bat species with dark fur and a preference for roosting in trees and old buildings.
Wild Horse - A free-roaming equine species, ancestors of domesticated horses, known for their endurance and resilience.
Squirrels - Agile, tree-dwelling rodents with bushy tails, found in woodlands and urban parks.
Noctule Bats - One of the largest UK bat species, flying at high altitudes to hunt insects.
Shrews - Tiny, insect-eating mammals with high metabolisms and a need to eat frequently.
Lesser White-toothed Shrew - A small, fast-moving shrew species with white-tipped teeth.
White-beaked Dolphin - A robust, social dolphin species with a distinctive pale beak, found in North Atlantic waters.
Domestic Ferret - A domesticated member of the weasel family, known for its playful and curious nature.
Mice Genus - A diverse group of small rodents adapted to various habitats worldwide.
Bechstein’s Bat - A rare woodland bat with large ears, often found roosting in tree hollows.
Wildcat-Domestic Cat Hybrid - A cross between the European wildcat and a domestic cat, often found in the wild.
Ferret-Polecat Hybrid - A hybrid between domesticated ferrets and wild polecats, displaying characteristics of both.
Black Rat - An adaptable rodent with a long tail and sharp climbing abilities, historically associated with the spread of plague.
Irish Hare - A native hare species of Ireland, larger and stockier than the brown hare.
Humpback Whale - A large, migratory baleen whale known for its acrobatic breaches and haunting songs.
Red-necked Wallaby - A medium-sized marsupial native to Australia, introduced to parts of the UK.
Greater White-toothed Shrew - A small shrew species with a long snout and white-tipped teeth, recently recorded in the UK.
Common Vole - A small, stocky rodent with a blunt snout, common in grasslands and meadows.
Eastern Grey Squirrel - An invasive squirrel species in the UK, larger and more dominant than the native red squirrel.
European Hedgehog - A nocturnal, spiny mammal that feeds on insects, commonly found in gardens.
Soprano Pipistrelle Bat - A small bat species that echolocates at a higher frequency than the common pipistrelle.
Common Pipistrelle Bat - The UK's most widespread bat species, known for its fluttery flight and insectivorous diet.
